dimension: 7 blocks along x, 1 block along y (height), 2 blocks along z. Extends from y = 0 (ground) up to y = 1.
position: Center the build on (0,0,0) so that x ranges from -3 to +3, and z from 0 to +1 (for instance). The top of this foundation finishes at y = 1.
tips: You can make this base a fully solid 7×2 layer to provide a sturdy look. If you prefer a flush front face, you can shift the second row so that only 1 block protrudes in front.
description: This single-layer stone_bricks platform acts as a thick footing for the wall, adding a defensive look.

dimension: 7 blocks along x, 2 blocks tall (y = 1 to y = 3), 2 blocks along z
position: Place directly on top of the foundation, spanning from y = 1 to y = 3. Match the same 7×2 footprint in the x–z plane.
tips: Build two full rows (each 7 wide × 2 deep) so that the wall is 2 blocks thick. Ensure a smooth front face and leave the rear side for a possible walkway if desired.
description: The primary defensive face of the structure, forming a solid wall about 2 blocks tall above the foundation.

dimension: 7 blocks along x, 1 block tall (y = 3 to y = 4), 2 blocks along z
position: Placed on top of the main wall, from y = 3 to y = 4. Align with the same 7×2 footprint.
tips: To create crenellations, place a row of stone_bricks along the front edge and the back edge, then remove every other block (or whichever pattern you like). Maintain consistent gaps to emulate a classic castle battlement design. If you want a walkway behind the battlements, leave the row fully in place on the back edge.
description: This top section provides the iconic “castle” look, with raised blocks (merlons) and open spaces (crenels) for archers or decoration.
